captions.text:
Seoul, South Korea. On immediate glance you'll
probably notice that shopping and dining are

two of Seoul's most prominent features, but
after a little more research and wandering

around, you'll notice that there's a rich
history, mountains and parks, countless neighborhoods,
and an interesting Korean culture.

The list of attractions in Seoul could go
on and on, that's why instead of trying to

tackle the entire city, I'd limit this list
to just twenty five of the coolest things
to do.

This is an overview that includes a little
history, a little shopping, food and eating,

and everything entertaining. If you want to
add something, to this list, please feel free
to leave a comment below.

Number one is the Gyeongbukgung Palace, originally
constructed at the end of the fourteenth century,

during the Jeonsong dynasty. And I just got
my ticket, three thousand won which is about

three US dollars. The coolest part about this
palace are these giant earthenware clay pots,

and they were used once back in the day to
store the chili pastes, the soy bean, the
fermented soy beans, maybe even kim chi.

Ok, I'm at the Bukchon Hanok Village, which
is a traditional Korean village, nowadays

it's quite a tourist attraction, but you just
follow this map around, and you go to a number

of different viewpoints, and lets go check
out these buildings.

The temple is one of the centers of Zen Buddhism
in Korea. One of the coolest things about

visiting the temple was the ancient trees
on the compound, apparently over five hundred

years old and strung with brightly colored
lanterns.

The Hwaseong Fortress is now a UNESCO world
heritage site, and one of South Koreas most

important historical sites. Ok, I'm going
to start the ascent up to the fortress walls.

So, I don't know how long this will take,
but it doesn't look that high.

Korean war memorial monument right now. It's
a pretty cool place actually.

Although a communications tower, it doubles
as an observation tower as well.

Number seven is the area of Myeongdong. Shopaholics
will rejoice when they go to Myeongdong, it's

one of Seoul's busiest and most shopper insane
areas of town.

One of Seoul's most touristy areas of town
is known as Insadong, If you're looking for

Korean souvenirs to bring back, this is a
great, yet kind of expensive place to buy
things.

Coming in at number nine is the Namdaemun
Market, located in the central area of Seoul,

and it's one of the cities largest and oldest
markets. This is Seoul in its most thrilling
local flavor.

Yet another wild shopping destination, Dongdaemun
is not really a single market, but rather
an entire area that is dedicated to shopping.

One of the international melting pots of Seoul
is Itaewon. There are lots of international
restaurants, stores, bars and clubs.

Another popular area of Seoul is near Hongik
University, known as Hongdae for short.

Lotte Mart has to be one of the coolest grocery
stores I've ever visited.

Step inside and you'll be transported into
a world of thrilling rides and adventurous
activities.

After walking around for a while, I realized,
it's a giant green park, with not just cool

things for kids, but for just about everyone.
I got to see my first ever polar bears at
the zoo within the park.

Along the banks of the river, throughout most
of the city, is a lovely recreational area
set aside for exercising and sports.

In an effort to renew the greenness in a seemingly
endless city sprawl, in central Seoul, the

Cheonggyecheon Stream and recreational area
was created.

Namsan is located right in the middle of Seoul,
but there are also many places to hike near
the city.

Without doubt, if you like to eat, indulging
in Korean street food at the Gwangjang Market

will be one of the top things to do in Seoul.
For myself, it was probably the coolest thing
I did.

Number twenty is Seoul's Noryangjin Fisheries
Market, a bedazzling display of the finest

and freshest seafood. The seafood is kept
so fresh in water that it's sometimes looks

like you're in a pet store instead of a food
market, isn't that awesome.

Garak Market is the biggest and craziest distribution
wholesale food market in Seoul. Food comes

to this market from around the entire country
to supply the city.

One of the finest things to do in Seoul is
to explore with your stomach. Much of the

street food in Seoul is made for on the go
eater who just have a few moments to grab

a quick snack. The food is served piping hot
and is fresh and extremely tasty. Deep fried
items and hot dogs are popular choices.

Korean really know how to make ice cream well,
and not just fresh ice cream, but some of

the best ice cream packages I've ever had
are sold at Korean convenience stores.

I don't think I've ever seen as many coffee
shops per block as in Seoul. The problem is,

it happens to be way watered down, and not
nearly strong enough, but the coffee shops

are still nice to sit in, and normally include
wifi.

It all eventually comes down to the food,
and Seoul, South Korea, is literally a heaven

on earth. At number twenty five is the Korea
barbecue. Sitting at a table with your own

personal grill in front of you, ordering plates
of meat and grilling them right before your

nose, and devouring the meat along with Korean
side dishes, and leaves of lettuce and garlic,

is one of the world's most delicious ways
to feast.

During my entire visit, I was enthralled and
confused at the same time, debating what to

eat and trying to eat as much South Korean
food as possible.

So there you have twenty five exciting things
to do in Seoul. But like I said before, this

is by no means everything there is to do in
Seoul, so if you have any other suggestions,
please leave a comment below and let me know!

title: 25 Best Things To Do in Seoul, South Korea

comments.text:
I have done all of these except for Lotte World and Garak market. And 
actually Hwaesong Fortress (number 4) is in Suwon.
Some other good mentions are:
1. Namhansanseong just southeast of Seoul in Gyeonggi-do. You can get a 
good view of the city on top of the mountain and it is a UNESCO world 
heritage site.
2. If you like live shows check out JUMP or NANTA.
3. A sobering place to visit is the Seodaemun Prison. There is a lot of 
history about how the Japanese treated the Koreans.
4. Go to Dream Forrest in Beondong. There is an interesting observatory 
there, which will give you a good view of the city and local surroundings.
5, Ttukseom Park is fun. There is a candy-cane shaped "Museum/coffee 
shop/art structure under the bridge by the Han River.
6. Dongdaemun Design Plaza makes you feel like you are walking through 
Starfleet Academy and there is a lot of shopping nearby.
7. There used to be a wall that surrounded Seoul once upon a time. Check 
out the history of it and the restoration at Seoul City Wall Museum near 
Dongdaemun station.﻿
comments.author: Rollogic

comments.author: Rishit Bhatt

comments.text: Well, how'd it go? Have a good trip?
comments.author: Rollogic

comments.text:
Just got back from Seoul. We only had 4 days there so we didn't do 
everything on this list but what we did do I enjoyed a lot. Seoul is an 
awesome city. The Koreans are also very nice and helpful. More Americans 
should travel there. Seoul is my favorite city. It is very clean as well. 
LOVE IT!!! cant wait to back when its a little warmer. The food was amazing 
as well.﻿
comments.author: Sean Cirino

comments.text:
+K-popalicious You are right. I cannot judge a city after only four days 
spent there. For me it was also a learning experience and maybe I had too 
high expectations. That may be because I had great experiences in the 
neighbouring countries I visited, or maybe because I have a few Korean 
friends and they are all very nice and interesting people.
Anyway, I may give it a second try in the future and see if with more time 
and better preparation I have a better experience there.
comments.author: manut975

comments.text:
+manut975 It takes time to get to know Seoul. I was there for 5 days but I 
wish I could return. At least it was a learning experience. Yes I totally 
agree with knowing some basic Korean because I became very frustrated at 
not knowing how to communicate in their language well enough. I will 
recommend anybody serious about going to Korea to spend at least 1 year 
studying Korean before going there. One exception is if you are Chinese 
going there to shop. Especially if you go to Myeongdong because the 
retailers there actually learn Chinese in order to target the Chinese 
tourists. Yes there are heaps of Chinese tourists in Korea.
comments.author: K-popalicious

comments.text:
+manut975
 I have lived in Seoul for 2.5 years and agree that it is actually a dirty, 
sometimes stinky city, but I have experienced different in that I have 
never had the trouble with speaking English or getting people to know what 
I want. A majority of people (especially young people) know quite a bit of 
the foreign language (English).
comments.author: Rollogic

comments.text:
Just come back from Seoul. We had 4 days there and we did many of the 
things on the list. Seoul is a grey and dirty city. The Koreans are very 
arrogant. They are also xenophobic. I have visited most big cities in Asia 
and I loved most of them, so of course I recommend other places in the 
area, like Japan or Taiwan. However, if you really decide to waste your 
time and money there, learn at least some basic Korean, because nobody 
there can understand even the basic English and transliteration of Korean 
is almost non-existent in most places.
comments.author: manut975

comments.text:
+Chris Jordan Ah, ya. Im not saying  there wasn't a time or two when 
someone wasn't short with us or somewhat rude, that's going to come with 
any big city. But, what im saying is there were numerous times when someone 
that I wasn't buying anything from provided help and direction when they 
didn't need to.

comments.author: ckim1

comments.text:
I lived there for over a year teaching English, and did most of the things 
on your list (mostly by chance). Sleep on a park bench on the Han river? 
Sleep under the N. Seoul tower? Good times. (I wasn't poor, but had not 
discovered the joy of their bath houses yet). Things your missed (in 
English), bath houses, singing rooms, dance clubs, BASEBALL (how did you 
miss this?!?) I must have gone to 60+ ball games across Korea (most fun I 
have ever had at a sporting event, was on the NC DINOS "fan club" and had 
front row/field seats every game I went to, Koreans are not the nicest 
people, but when you become friends, life long friends). Probably lots 
more, but if you think Korea is shit you need your head examined.﻿
comments.author: 123123bradbrad

comments.text:
+Charlie Fan  Have you tried the Chinese food in Korea? It's probably the 
only foreign food that is actually better than the states, imo.  Most of 
the Chinese restaurants in Korea have a nice crispy, carmalized, juicy 
taste that is often mushy in the states, for the fried meat dishes.  
Chaijang mien also seems cleaner tasting in Korea than the USA.

comments.text:
+Master Yi I live in LA now. And go to Seoul often. I don't agree with you. 
Korean food is better in Korea. Maybe you aren't used to it having less 
meat. US has most food issues GMO. also Chinese food isn't authentic in the 
US. Its Americanized Chinese. I am talking about food sold at restaurants 
now. Chinese food in Korea. Japan. US are not the same
comments.author: chosonnom

comments.text:
I'm Korean American from Socal currently in Seoul for 1 year now.  I've 
realized the food SUCKS here, straight up. Especially compared to a food 
mecca like Los Angeles.  Basically, everyone saying why food in Korea sucks 
is usually on-point in some way.  Korean food is better in LA than Seoul.  
I've been through countless tantrums before being forced to cook my own 
meals daily.  Props to Emart and foreign markets, but still, supermarket 
ingredients not the same as American supermarkets.

Jim Jil Bangs!  Korea has some of the largest Sauna-Spas and it is the best 
way to relax and unwind.  Koreans do this regularly...they are open 24/7 
and there is so much to do at these places for only about $10-$20.  Get the 
body scrubbing massage...they do this on the regular, which I think is part 
of the reason their skin is so soft and beautiful!﻿
